learning_outcomes.description: Develop an understanding of the spectrum of security threats in contemporary world politics.
Identify and appreciate the different foundational assumptions of established and critical theories of International Relations and their implications for policy and practice.
Demonstrate critical reflexive thinking about the political and ethical dilemmas of policy and practice addressing security threats.
Demonstrate an understanding of effective, ethical and localised practice.
Ability to develop theoretically informed and evidenced based recommendations for policy and practice addressing local and global security challenges.

assessments.task_description:
Part One: Participation and News Wrap Contribution (10%)

In Weeks 1-10, students are expected to come to class with at least one story from the past week’s news. This story or event must be related to international politics, and should relate to the course topics, ideas, or themes. At the beginning of each seminar, students will have a 10 minute “news wrap” where they will discuss their news item in small groups. Each student will then be required to post a summary of their news story/event to the Padlet for that seminar with a critical reflection of that event: how can it be understood through the theories covered in the course, and what are the potential implications of that event? The corresponding Padlet link will only be made available during class. There is 1 mark available per seminar assessed (seminars 1-10), totalling 10 marks (10%)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Part Two: Positionality Reflection (5%)

This task invites students to submit a 500 word self-reflexive discussion of their learning journey throughout the semester, their identity, values, assumptions, ethical stance/s, and their key takeaways as they think about what a career in International Politics “means” to them. 5 marks are available for this reflection. This reflection must be submitted via Turnitin by Friday 29 May. It will not be formally assessed and no feedback will be provided, but it will be checked to ensure you have completed the exercise and are eligible to receive these five additional marks. 

Sample questions to help guide your reflection:

  • What do I want to achieve in a career in international politics? What are my motivations, and why?
  • What does it mean to translate theory into policy or practice? What is the relationship between these components of international politics?
  • What does power and legitimacy mean to me in international politics?
  • How does my own intersectional identity, personal experiences, and academic and professional background shape my engagement in international politics? How should these factors influence practice?
  • What are the primary challenges or dilemmas that I anticipate I may encounter in a career in international politics?

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
You will be required to pick an international political event/news story/conflict/dilemma/structural challenge within a specific context. Imagine a scenario where you have been asked by your employer to clearly and concisely present what is known about that situation before strategic engagement. Your task is to write a 1500-word scoping assessment outlining the key areas of concern including 1) identifying who the key actors or stakeholders are, 2) the socio-political, gender, cultural, and economic factors that need to be considered, and 3) some recommendations for how these factors may be sensitively navigated. You are not required to offer any solutions to the issue, but rather, landscape all of the important considerations that need to be known before any type of strategic policy or practical intervention can take place. Your analysis and recommendations must be clearly informed by theory.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
Earlier in semester, you selected an international political event/news story/conflict/dilemma/structural challenge and wrote a Scoping Analysis of that issue. Using that same issue, you are now required to write either a Policy Brief or Project Proposal. Imagine that you are now tasked with preparing advice to your employer (this could be a national or local government agency, a grassroots civil society organisation, an international financial institution, a multilateral or a regional organisation etc.) on how this issue should be addressed through either a policy recommendation (in which case you will write a Policy Brief), or through some sort of practical engagement or intervention strategy (in which case you will write a Project Proposal). Instructions on how to write a Policy Brief and Project Proposal will be presented during seminars.

Your policy recommendation or intervention strategy must be concrete and sensitive to the context, aimed at addressing the particular political issue while navigating the sensitivities identified in your scoping analysis. Your analysis and recommendations must be clearly informed by theory. Your proposal should include:

  • A brief overview of the scenario and context.
  • A brief summary of the key actors/stakeholders and their relationship.
  • Identify the specific challenge or issue your policy or intervention strategy is seeking to address and explain why addressing this issue is a priority.
  • A clear and concise statement of your overall approach or policy proposal with a theory of change.
  • Justify the proposed method or steps to be taken and explain their suitability to the context and local sensitivities.
  • Identify the possible challenges to implementation, ethical risks, and limitations.
  • Detail how your proposed policy or intervention will be monitored and evaluated.

The word count for your proposal is 3000 words

assessments.task_description:
Due: 21-28 May during the last two seminars

Weight: 20%

Length: 5-minute presentation followed by 5 minutes Q&A

Description: You are now required to pitch your project proposal or policy recommendation to your employer. Imagine the course coordinator and fellow students represent your organisation. You will be given 5 minutes to present your issue analysis and project proposal or policy recommendation in class. After you present, you will be asked follow-up questions in order to demonstrate your knowledge and capacities. You will have 5 minutes of Q&A. Presentations will take place in the final two weeks of class (seminars 12 and 13 on 21 and 28 May). You must ensure you are able to attend these two seminars.
